cleanText: MELBOURNE, Australia—Glencore PLC could further prune its coal output to help reduce the market glut that has helped drive the commodity's prices to multiyear lows. In a rare public presentation, Glencore's Australia-based head of global coal assets, Peter Freyberg, insisted coal was “a very, very important part" of the company, and that executives were considering options to acquire new assets or tie up with other producers with an eye to the long-term. When Glencore closed its purchase of fellow miner Xstrata PLC two years ago, Chief Executive Ivan Glasenberg said the blockbuster deal was “a big play on coal." Since then, coal prices have fallen sharply, while Glencore's market value has dropped close to its lowest level since it floated in London and Hong Kong in 2011.

Money managers have been cutting back their bets on oil in the run up to the crucial meeting of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries in Vienna this week. The number of bets taken by hedge funds and other big investors on the global oil benchmark Brent—comprising bets on both rising and falling prices—has fallen to just over 320,000, the equivalent of 320 million barrels of oil, its lowest level in nine months. The number of bets on West Texas Intermediate, the U.S. gauge, is at its lowest since the beginning of January. The $2.5 billion United States Oil Fund LP, the largest U.S. exchange-traded fund investing in U.S. oil futures, has also drawn back, registering outflows of close to $1 billion in the past two months, according to investment research company Morningstar. In April, the fund lost $550 million, the biggest withdrawal since 2011. It lost another $390 million in May, the data shows.
headline: Fund Managers Cut Oil Bets Ahead of

cleanText: The battle of the Samsungs has begun in earnest. Minority investors gained momentum on two fronts Thursday, improving the odds that ordinary shareholders won't be run over by the controlling Lee family.                 Paul Singer's hedge fund Elliott Management disclosed it has  worth $628 million in Samsung C&T, intending to oppose a merger with Cheil Industries, the Lee family's de facto holding company. It sets up a classic dust-up between an American hedge fund and the most powerful family in South Korea's cozy business world.                                                                              Elliott's stand is justified. The deal between Cheil and C&T would  over the Samsung empire, but values C&T . C&T shares rose 10% in response, an encouraging sign that investors think Elliott's presence will force the family to sweeten the terms.
headline: Elliott Launches Battle for the Heart of

cleanText: CANBERRA, Australia—Australia says it expects more asylum seekers to choose resettlement in Cambodia after four refugees arrived in the Southeast Asian nation under a deal that has drawn United Nations criticism. Three Iranians and one ethnic Rohingya from Myanmar became the first of the 677 asylum seekers  to be voluntarily resettled under a . “There are a lot of people in Nauru at the moment who are interested in following these four," Australia's Immigration Minister Peter Dutton told Australian television on Thursday, confirming the four had arrived in Phnom Penh several hours before.
headline: Australia-Cambodia Asylum Deal Gets Four Takers; Four migrants who had sought asylum in Australia—only to be detained with hundreds of others on Nauru—accept resettlement in Cambodia

cleanText: BUJUMBURA, Burundi—Presidential and parliamentary elections have been postponed in Burundi, an official said Thursday, following weeks of unrest in the capital over President Pierre Nkurunziza's bid for a third term in office. Presidential adviser for media and information Willy Nyamitwe said officials are waiting for a proposal from the electoral commission on the new dates for elections. Parliamentary elections were scheduled for Friday while presidential polls were slated for June 26. Burundi's capital, Bujumbura, has been rocked by  following the April 25 announcement of Mr. Nkurunziza's bid for a third term in office. At least 20 people have died in street battles with police. The protests  in mid-May which was crushed in 48 hours.
headline: Burundi Presidential Elections Postponed; Move follows weeks of unrest over President Nkurunziza’s bid for a third term in office

cleanText: TOKYO—Apple Inc. priced its first ever yen-denominated bonds Thursday, in one of the largest offerings of yen-denominated debt by a non-Japanese issuer in recent years. The U.S. tech giant will offer ¥250 billion ($2 billion) in five-year yen-denominated bonds with a coupon of 0.350%, according to a term sheet. The issue will let Apple take advantage of Japan's superlow borrowing rates. Market participants have said the terms have already drawn much attention as they are offering significantly more than yields on domestic bonds. The five-year Japanese government bond yield was 0.115% late on Thursday in Asia.
headline: Apple Prices Yen Bond Offering; Tech giant to offer five-year yen-denominated bond to Japanese, international investors

cleanText: YANGON, Myanmar—Myanmar's foreign minister said Thursday that the thousands of boat migrants who have washed up on Southeast Asian shores in recent weeks are mostly Bangladeshis fleeing poverty, rejecting charges that persecution in his country is to blame. Minister of Foreign Affairs Wunna Maung Lwin said conditions in Myanmar's Rakhine state, where about 140,000 Rohingya Muslims are confined to squalid camps without citizenship, “are not the root cause" that drove migrants to pay for passage on smuggling boats. After a crackdown on human trafficking in Thailand, thousands of Bangladeshis and Rohingya Muslims were . Mr. Wunna Maung Lwin accused the rescued migrants of “taking advantage of the situation in Rakhine state" and pretending they are from Myanmar. They aren't fleeing persecution nor are they even mostly from Myanmar, he said at a briefing for diplomats and the media, but instead are predominantly people from Bangladesh seeking better job opportunities.
headline: Myanmar Rejects Blame for Human-Trafficking Crisis; Foreign minister says conditions in Myanmar didn’t drive Rohingya Muslim migrants to pay for passage on smuggling boats

cleanText: HONG KONG—Alibaba Pictures Group Ltd., the film unit of the Chinese e-commerce giant, is selling up to 12.18 billion Hong Kong dollars (US$1.57 billion) in shares to raise capital to fund potential acquisitions in the media industry. Alibaba Pictures, formerly ChinaVision Media Group Ltd. before Alibaba Group Holding bought it out in June last year, said Thursday it has agreed to sell 4.20 billion new shares at HK$2.9 each to independent investors, representing around 16.64% of its enlarged share capital. A person with knowledge of the transaction said the shares are being placed privately with around 20 to 30 investors. Half of those are high net worth, he said, while the rest are hedge funds and pension funds.
headline: Alibaba Pictures Raises $1.57 Billion From Share Sale; Alibaba Pictures’ stock has surged on expectations that its parent will inject assets into it

cleanText: China's stock market suffered one of its biggest falls this year before staging a dramatic recovery to end in positive territory, adding to a week of large and sudden moves amid jitters over a clampdown on lending to investors. The Shanghai Composite Index, which had been up as much as 0.7% earlier in Asia trading, fell as much as 5.3% after the midday break Thursday before recovering almost as rapidly, closing up 0.8%. The smaller slumped as much as 6.2% before closing down 0.6%, while the ChiNext index, which tracks small-cap stocks and has increased threefold in the past year, slid as much as 7.2% before ending the day down 1%. It was a day of turmoil for other markets in the region too, with Asia's bond markets unnerved by yields on government debt .
headline: China Shares Ride a Roller Coaster; Shanghai market recovers from heavy afternoon fall on margin-financing concerns

cleanText: SHANGHAI—Chinese authorities have halted operations of the sister ship of the vessel that capsized Monday night on the Yangtze River, according to state media. Yangtze River authorities on Thursday ordered Chongqing Eastern Shipping Corp., the owner of the ill-fated Eastern Star, to suspend the operations of its sister vessel, the Eastern Pearl, and to carry out a comprehensive investigation of the rest of its fleet, according to China's state-run Xinhua News Agency. The Eastern Pearl has the same design as the Eastern Star that sank with 456 people on board, the report said.
headline: China Grounds Sister Ship of Capsized Yangtze Vessel; Eastern Pearl has same design as the Eastern Star, which sank with 456 people on board

cleanText: HANOI—“A Vietnamese salad," proclaims the French chef Raphaël Le Mancq, “is a garden." A wild, untamed one. Leaves, stalks, seeds, flowers—nothing goes to waste. While some cultures nibble delicately at the greenest shoots, the Vietnamese devour the whole lot. But this is very French, too. That's why Mr. Le Mancq, who owns the Michelin-starred restaurant Le Sérac in the French ski resort of Saint-Gervais-les-Bains, feels so at home as he prepares a fusion dinner for several dozen guests at the lakeside villa of Loan de Leo Foster, one of Hanoi's most fashionable hostesses.
headline: Vietnam’s Untamed Cuisine; At a lakeside villa in Hanoi, a French chef celebrates the country’s bounty of explosively fresh vegetables and herbs

cleanText: BEIJING—China's government urged its steel businesses, collectively the largest in the world, to launch lawsuits to defend themselves against a rising tide of international trade complaints, including those from the U.S., its commerce ministry said. “We encourage Chinese steelmakers and related businesses to actively participate in countersuits, and protect their legitimate interests according to World Trade Organization rules," the ministry said this week. The ministry's stance comes as rising Chinese steel exports run into resistance from competitors at the destinations of its shipments.
headline: China Steels Itself Against Trade Complaints; China’s government urges steelmakers to counter trade complaints they are flooding the market with steel exports

cleanText: The economics of transportation are built on scale, right? Maybe not when it comes to the new generation of big container ships, which appear to be sailing in troubled waters. A new analysis from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development contends the steep rate-cutting that has arrived with the ships, and the added time the cargo handling consumes, . And, as WSJ Logistics Report's Robbie Whelan writes, the OECD has an especially troubling message for companies and governments that are investing in new ship-handling infrastructure: Along “the whole transport chain," the ships' economic benefits don't come close to matching the costs they must take on to retrofit ports.  Maybe U.S. exporters don't have it so bad, after all. As the WSJ's Jeffrey Sparshott writes, the  in April. That was in part because exports expanded 1% over the month before as the impact of the West Coast ports cargo backlogs dissipated. Analysts still believe the strong U.S. dollar will cut into the country's exports over the long term, but some American companies are reporting new interest from developing countries such as the Philippines and India that are looking for materials and equipment to back infrastructure investment. The countries are trying to jumpstart their economies, and that means more demand for American exporters.  Consumers may not be getting the message that online retail sales are supposed to pull them away from brick-and-mortar stores. A new survey by United Parcel Service Inc. and comScore Inc. of 5,100 U.S. consumers suggests that many buyers aren't simply sitting back and waiting for deliveries. Instead, the WSJ's Laura Stevens reports, about half of those surveyed have had an order shipped to a store for pickup, and 45% of those shoppers bought something else while fetching their online order. It's a significant result that . That is, many retailers that are seeing Amazon.com use its e-commerce platform to take business from traditional sellers now believe that a hybrid approach combining a strong online presence, a familiar storefront and the ability to manage inventory nimbly across both platforms may be the best strategy.
headline: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From WSJ; Delivering up-to-the-minute news, analysis, interviews and explanatory journalism on logistics, supply-chain management, e-commerce and more

cleanText: The U.S. government fined a Pacific island casino operator $75 million for what it called “willful and egregious" violations of anti-money-laundering rules going back to 2008. The Treasury's Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, or FinCEN, Wednesday hit the Tinian Dynasty Hotel & Casino on the Northern Mariana Islands, a U.S. commonwealth, with the civil fine, which was the biggest ever issued against a casino by FinCEN and the fourth largest ever imposed on any entity by the agency, said spokesman Steve Hudak. The penalty is a sign that FinCEN is acting after issuing warnings to casinos to step up their efforts to prevent money laundering. The previous top penalty against a casino was a  in March, which at the time was seen as an increase in enforcement.
headline: U.S. Fines Pacific Island Casino Operator $75 Million for Anti-Money-Laundering Violations; The Tinian Dynasty Hotel & Casino on the Northern Mariana Islands faces the biggest fine issued by FinCEN against a casino

cleanText: 0854 GMT [Dow Jones]--The continued selloff in the eurozone government bond market, driven by Bunds, forces U.S. Treasury yields back to levels last seen in October 2014. The 10-yr Bund is 11 bps higher at 0.975% and the U.S. Treasury 10-yr is quoted at 2.415%. The continued Bund sell-off is driven by growing expectations of a positive Greece/IMF repayment outcome, ECB warnings of increased volatility, and a marginally higher inflation outlook. Ahead initial jobless claims before Friday's labor stats. (nick.cawley@wsj.com)

0832 GMT [Dow Jones]--The euro continues to power ahead as the yield on the 10-year bond spikes another 10 basis points. EUR/USD is now up 1% on the day at a fresh two-week high 1.1346, EUR/JPY a five-month high of 140.70, EUR/GBP a fresh one-month high 0.7382 and EUR/CHF a two-month high of 1.0558. (gary.stride@wsj.com) .
headline: Euro Powers Ahead; EUR/JPY likely to consolidate with bullish bias near-term after hitting near-five-month high 140.13 this morning

cleanText: NEW DELHI—India will hold the second-largest portion of shares and voting rights in a new China-led infrastructure investment bank that is expected to start operations by end of the year, a senior Indian official said. China's shareholding in the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, or AIIB, is expected to be around 30%, while that of India will be around 8%, the official, who didn't want to be identified, said Thursday. The official said India's vote share is likely to be around 7.5%. The shareholdings and voting rights of all  of the bank were finalized recently in Singapore on the basis of the countries' respective gross domestic products and purchasing power parity, said the official familiar with the developments.
headline: India to Have Second-Largest Shareholding in China-Led Bank; India’s shareholding in

cleanText: As Congress is set to battle over the authorization of President Obama's trade authority and the extension of the Export-Import Bank, the ideological wings of both parties are set to clash with the more centrist, pro-business lawmakers.
headline: Jerry Seib: Center Stage for Fast Track, Ex-Im

cleanText: BEIJING—A Chinese government agency is renewing efforts to fight the online sale of knockoffs, five months after backing down from a rare public dispute with e-commerce giant Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. over counterfeits and other issues. The State Administration for Industry and Commerce, or SAIC, said in a statement on its website Thursday it was launching a campaign dubbed Red Shield Net Sword, aimed at purging fake and substandard goods from online trading sites. The campaign will run from July to November, the notice said. The regulator carried out a similar campaign against online counterfeits last year that it said resulted in 1.33 million inspections of websites and online stores, the removal of 36,000 listings of merchandise, closures of 2,201 websites, and fines and confiscated funds amounting to 113 million yuan ($18.2 million). Still, brand owners and intellectual property rights experts say .
headline: Chinese Regulator Announces New Crackdown on Online Sales of Fakes; The campaign called Red Shield Net Sword aims to purge the sale of fake and subpar goods online

cleanText: A selloff in global bond markets is hitting Asian government debt hard, with prices plunging and yields in some countries jumping to their highest in years. In Singapore, yields on 10-year bonds hit their highest level in almost two years, while yields in Australia hit their highest level of 2015, yields in Japan hit their highest level since November and yields in Thailand jumped 0.1 percentage point Thursday. It's a sharp turnaround for Asian bonds, which have rallied this year as investors flocked to the high-yield market seeking alternatives to the near-zero returns of other global markets.
headline: Bond Selloff Slams Asia; Yields on some government debt jumps to highest level in years

cleanText: 0920 GMT [Dow Jones]--Spot gold prices are lower, trading down 0.2% at $1,182.95/oz, as optimism over the likelihood of Greece reaching a deal with its creditors weighed on the safe-haven metal. And the losses could increase. “Precious metals are edging lower despite the weaker dollar and gold looks on course to retest support at $1,180/oz, with further potential support at $1,170/oz," says William Adams, head of research at Fastmarkets. (ese.erheriene@wsj.com; Twitter: @Ese_Journo)
headline: Spot Gold Down on Greece Optimism; Spot gold isn’t getting the usual support it might from a rally in EUR/USD and was trading at 1184.83 per ounce in early Asian trade.

cleanText: DUBAI—Iran's supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said Thursday that the U.S. and other arrogant powers couldn't be trusted, as the deadline approaches for a nuclear deal that could result in the easing of international sanctions against Iran. “We see how it is impossible to trust the promises of the arrogants," he said, “and how we can't rely on words said in private meetings." Mr. Khamenei, who has the final say over most matters of state in Iran, made the comments in a speech marking the anniversary of the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the driving force behind the country's Islamic revolution in 1979.
headline: Iran’s Supreme Leader Says U.S. Cannot Be Trusted; Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said ‘the arrogants’ couldn’t be trusted, as deadline for nuclear deal nears

cleanText: Oil prices remained under pressure on Thursday despite declining U.S. supplies as investors braced for the outcome of a key meeting of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries. Brent crude for July delivery recently fell 0.7% to $63.36 a barrel on London's ICE Futures exchange. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate futures for July were trading down 0.6% at $59.28 a barrel. Investors shrugged off reports Wednesday that commercial stockpiles of U.S. crude oil fell by 1.9 million barrels last week, the fifth-straight weekly decline, according to the U.S. Energy Information Administration.
headline: Oil Prices Fall Ahead of

cleanText: 0854 GMT [Dow Jones]--The continued selloff in the eurozone government bond market, driven by Bunds, forces U.S. Treasury yields back to levels last seen in October 2014. The 10-yr Bund is 11 bps higher at 0.975% and the U.S. Treasury 10-yr is quoted at 2.415%. The continued Bund sell-off is driven by growing expectations of a positive Greece/IMF repayment outcome, ECB warnings of increased volatility, and a marginally higher inflation outlook. Ahead initial jobless claims before Friday's labor stats. (nick.cawley@wsj.com)

BRUSSELS—Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and his country's international creditors were able to agree on some aspects of a financing deal at a meeting Wednesday night, but differences remain on some key issues, European officials said Thursday. “The next hours, the next days…are absolutely essential," said Pierre Moscovici, the European Union's economics commissioner. “I would say I'm optimistic." Mr. Tsipras will submit a counter offer to his country's creditors, including the rest of the eurozone and the International Monetary Fund, two officials said. They spoke after the Greek prime minister held late-night talks with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker and Jeroen Dijsselbloem, the Dutch finance minister who represents the currency union's national governments in the talks.
headline: Greece and Its Creditors Agree on Some Measures in Bailout Talks; ‘Combative’ negotiations resume after ‘some aspects of a financing deal’ agreed overnight

cleanText: LONDON—Oil prices rose on Thursday on a weakening dollar but remained under pressure as investors braced for the outcome of a key meeting of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries. Brent crude for July delivery recently rose 0.2% to $63.90 a barrel reversing earlier losses on London's ICE Futures exchange. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate futures for July were trading up 0.3% at $59.83 a barrel. The Wall Street Journal Dollar Index fell 0.2% on Thursday providing a lift to dollar-priced commodities like oil which become more attractive to holders of other currencies as the greenback depreciates.
headline: Oil Prices Rise on Weakening Dollar;

cleanText: Good morning, Wage Weakness When U.S. unemployment rates fall, simple rules of labor supply and demand predict wages will go up. But a  to persistent constraints on worker pay, even as the economy approaches what the data say is full employment. The Journal found 33 U.S. metropolitan areas where unemployment rates and nonfarm payrolls last year returned to prerecession levels. But even in those regions, pay raises typically were small as large numbers of former workers who had become detached from the labor force filled many of the available jobs. Check out this sampling of  by Fed economists in Washington and across the system's 12 regional reserve banks on the subject of wages. And here's a look at the  has lagged job growth.
headline: The 10-Point. A personal, guided tour to the best scoops and stories every day in The Wall Street Journal, from Editor in Chief

cleanText: SINGAPORE—Economic sluggishness in Europe and the U.S. isn't prompting Singapore Airlines Ltd. to scale back in those markets, and the island nation's flag carrier will also continue to build out its Southeast Asian network, its chief executive said. “We have not retreated [from European or U.S. routes]," Goh Choon Phong said Thursday. “We will selectively grow into areas where we think traffic is," he added, citing the example of London, where Singapore Airlines increased flights in 2012 by starting a fourth daily service. Singapore Airlines also added flights to Munich and Copenhagen in recent years, but it has seen its market share fall steadily because of competition from aggressive Persian Gulf-based carriers, who have increased the number of seats on offer to Singapore by 20% over the last 12 months, according to a report by aviation industry consulting firm CAPA Centre for Aviation.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa—MasterCard Worldwide this week started issuing credit cards in Somalia in a bid to tap the $1.6 billion annual remittances business that has been disrupted by U.S. and U.K. banks suspending their services on fears of inadvertently being involved in money laundering or terrorist financing. MasterCard is linking up with Somalia's Premier Bank and has already distributed its first credit cards to Somalis, after a three-year process to set up shop in the strife-torn nation in the Horn of Africa, said Daniel Monehin, division president for sub-Saharan Africa said. The move signals Mastercard's willingness to undertake risks in Africa, even going into the continent's most dangerous corners ahead of its key competitor, Visa. It also heralds a first step in lifting the effective financial blockade of Somalia.

DABBIS, Iraq—Just before Islamic State territory begins,  have built a dirt wall across the road. But they don't have much hope it would stop the militants' favorite way of breaking front lines—armored trucks filled with explosives and driven by suicide bombers. Lt. Jamal Derwish, the outpost's commander, said his men already spotted three such armored vehicles in the area since Islamic State, or ISIS,  and seized yet another arsenal of modern U.S.-made heavy weapons from the Iraqi army. Islamic State fighters, he said, have also filled trenches with oil to burn—something that would create a smokescreen to protect them from U.S. airstrikes. “We're facing a very serious threat. Without necessary weapons, this basic defensive line won't be enough," Lt. Derwish said shortly after his outpost came under Islamic State's mortar fire. He held up an old rocket-propelled grenade, something that wouldn't easily stop a massive armored truck barreling down the road.
headline: Kurdish Peshmerga Say They Need Weapons After ISIS Seizes Iraqi Arsenal; Forces worry they cannot hold defensive lines

cleanText: LONDON—The Bank of England kept its benchmark interest rate steady on Thursday after data showed consumer prices in the U.K. fell on the year in April for the first time in more than half a century. The BOE said policy makers on the rate-setting Monetary Policy Committee voted to keep the central bank's main interest rate at 0.5% and to leave the size of its bond portfolio unchanged at £375 billion ($578 billion) following their regular monthly meeting. The decision was as expected. Sterling and government bond prices were broadly unmoved.

Saudi oil minister Ali al-Naimi is the closest thing the oil industry has to a celebrity. His walks through Vienna during OPEC meetings have become a public spectacle, drawing journalists and industry observers.
headline: A Walk With

cleanText: Joy Global Inc. on Thursday said profit nearly halved in its latest quarter, as the mining equipment company continues to grapple with lower sales volumes resulting from oversupply and lower commodity prices. Still, adjusted earnings and revenue came in slightly ahead of analysts' expectations. The “results reflect increasing pressure on our end-markets from continued oversupplied conditions and sequentially declining commodity pricing," said Chief Executive Ted Doheny. “The incoming order rate, in particular in the U.S. coal and global copper markets slowed as customers further reduced capital expenditures and deferred maintenance on their mining equipment fleets."

Software developer SunGard Data Systems Inc. has filed for an initial public offering, about a decade after a group of private-equity firms acquired it in an $11 billion deal that helped usher in a wave of megabuyouts before the financial crisis. SunGard's private equity owners—Bain Capital, Blackstone Group LP, Goldman Sachs's private-equity arm, KKR & Co., Providence Equity Partners Inc., Silver Lake and TPG—will continue to own a majority voting power, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. SunGard said it plans to raise $100 million through the offering, though that number is a placeholder and is likely to change. The Wall Street Journal reported in May that the company was  around $750 million through the IPO.

Lands' End Inc. on Thursday reported that sales slid a worse-than-expected 9.4% in its first quarter as the company continues to struggles with retail softness and foreign-currency impacts. Lands' End was spun off from Sears Holdings Corp. in April 2014 as Sears sought to focus on its core assets. Sears acquired Lands' End in 2002 for $1.9 billion. For the quarter ended May 1, Lands' End reported a profit of $1.72 million, or five cents a share, down from $10.9 million, or 34 cents a share, a year earlier.
headline: Lands’ End Sales Continue to Slide; Revenue in the company’s direct business—Internet and catalog sales—fell 8.2%

cleanText: CAIRO—An Egyptian court ordered the retrial of ousted President Hosni Mubarak for complicity in the deaths of hundreds of demonstrators during a 2011 uprising against his regime, overturning a previous ruling acquitting him. The country's highest criminal court accepted appeals demanding a retrial of Mr. Mubarak and set its first session for Nov. 5, state television reported on Thursday. Cairo's Criminal Court had dropped the murder charges against Mubarak last November, simultaneously acquitting his interior minister, Habib el Adly, and six aides.
headline: Egyptian Court Orders Mubarak Retrial for Complicity in Protesters’ Deaths; Court overturns previous ruling acquitting him

cleanText: Cape Town, South Africa Floods shut down the capital of Ghana and caused a fire that killed scores of people on Wednesday and Thursday, as Accra's antiquated, colonial-era sewers struggled to clear water from a city that has doubled in size over recent decades. A moderate rain on Wednesday afternoon turned into a citywide disaster that evening, as roads, including the main boulevard that encircles the city of four million people, pooled with water, residents said. As dozens of people sought shelter at a gas station, the station flooded, then exploded, burning at least 80 of them alive in a blaze that firefighters worked overnight to put out, according to the state-owned Daily Graphic.
headline: Eighty Killed in Ghana Gas Station Fire Sparked by Flood; Antiquated sewers beneath Accra struggle to clear water from city that has doubled in size

cleanText: Michaels Cos. reported Thursday that sales increased 2.4% in the April quarter, despite currency headwinds and unfavorable weather early in the quarter. In addition, Michaels also pointed to the declining popularity of the Rainbow Loom toy, which had remained popular through the first half of last year. The company had enjoyed big-box exclusivity for the bracelet kit, driving a spike in sales, but the product's popularity has since faded. While Michaels dominates the arts-and-crafts retail segment, it faces growing competition from a number of smaller and online-only outlets.
headline: Michaels Revenue Increases 2.4%; Company says declining popularity of its Rainbow Loom toy hit sales

cleanText: Announcing that gold production is approaching its limits can be hazardous. In 2009 Aaron Regent, who shortly after became chief executive of Barrick Gold, said the world had reached “peak gold." Three years later, Mr. Regent was out of a job and mined gold output was still rising. Indeed, it hit a record 3,133 metric tons last year. Yet predictions of peak gold are again in vogue. It remains doubtful, however, that this heralds much elevation . Gold production may be plateauing: precious metals consultancy Metals Focus expects a slight fall in output this year. A decadelong rise in the gold price from 2001 fueled indiscriminate investment but miners have slashed spending since 2013. Substantial new mines, like Barrick's Pascua Lama in Chile, have been halted and exploration efforts scaled back.
headline: Gold’s Peak Doesn’t Mean New Price Heights; The industry has been in survival mode, companies warn

cleanText: J.M. Smucker Co. on Thursday gave a disappointing earnings forecast for its newly started fiscal year as the company saw volumes slide for many of its coffee and food products in the April quarter. For the year ending next April, Smucker forecast per-share earnings of $5.65 to $5.80, while analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had forecast $5.84 a share in earnings. Smucker forecast sales of about $8 billion, while analysts had forecast $7.97 billion in sales. Shares fell 1% to $117 a share in premarket trading.
headline: Smucker Gives Weak Forecast as Coffee, Food Volumes Continue to Slide; Volumes decline for Jif, Pillsbury, and Folgers products

cleanText: Navistar International Corp. on Thursday reported that revenue fell 1.9% in the April quarter, even as cost-cutting initiatives and margin improvements helped the company narrow its loss. The Lisle, Ill.-based company had been struggling to leverage market-share gains from the red-hot demand for commercial trucks in North America. It had been in fourth place in the market behind Volvo AB, Paccar Inc.-–the maker of Peterbilt and Kenworth trucks—and Daimler AG ‘s Freightliner unit. The company's market share began eroding in 2012 when the company's engines weren't able to comply with tougher federal standards for diesel-engine exhaust. Under Troy Clarke, who became chief executive in April 2013, Navistar fixed its engine problems and began using exhaust-treatment components and popular engine models built by Cummins Inc., moves that were expected to help Navistar recover market share.
headline: Navistar Revenue Falls 1.9%; Cost-cutting initiatives and margin improvements help company narrow loss

cleanText: TOKYO—Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company and Sumitomo Rubber Industries Ltd. have agreed to dissolve their alliance involving Dunlop and Goodyear brands dating back to 1999, the tire makers said Thursday. The move resolves some 17 months of arbitration that Goodyear, the world's third-biggest tire maker based on revenue, initiated in January 2014 to end the tie-up with Sumitomo Rubber Industries, the sixth-biggest tire maker. Goodyear said its 2015 and 2016 financial targets won't be affected as a result of the move. Sumitomo Rubber said it is studying whether there will be any impact on its financial outlook.
headline: Goodyear and

cleanText: Ciena Corp. swung to a profit in its latest quarter, as optical sales jumped and the Telecom-equipment maker saw growth across geographic regions. Better-than-expected results helped push shares 2.3% higher in premarket trading. Through Thursday's close, shares gained 27% this year. Higher demand in the optical-gear market has been helping the company improve its revenue in recent periods. Last month, Ciena  Cyan Inc., which provides software and platforms for network operators, for about $400 million. The move was Ciena's latest to upgrade and diversify its offerings while broadening its customer base.

South Korea reported a third death from an outbreak of Middle East Respiratory Syndrome on Thursday, as a rising number of cases added to public anxiety about the virus and kindergartens, schools and universities remained closed across the country. A 82-year-old man who died on Wednesday tested positive for MERS, the country's health ministry said. The man had been hospitalized since early last month after suffering from fever and shortness of breath and he was also being treated for asthma and pneumonia. He spent days in the same hospital rooms as previously-confirmed MERS patients, the ministry said.
headline: South Korea Reports Third Death as MERS Cases Rise; Latest cases raise the total number of South Korean MERS patients to 36

cleanText: SAN DIEGO—If Dillon Gee keeps pitching like this, the Mets might want to rethink the whole six-man rotation thing after all. Making his first start in a month, Gee lasted just four innings Wednesday night, surrendering seven runs (four earned) on eight hits in the Mets' 7-3 loss to the Padres. Gee, who landed on the disabled list on May 8 with a strained groin, snapped a streak of 51 consecutive starts completing at least five frames, a franchise record. Instead of removing somebody from the staff to accommodate Gee's return, the Mets simply added him into the mix as part of a continued effort to limit the workloads of some of their younger pitchers. In theory, it sounds like a fine plan: Keeping Gee around will shave innings off the ledgers of Matt Harvey, Jacob deGrom and Noah Syndergaard, allowing them all to remain active for a potential playoff run.
headline: Dillon Gee Pitches Himself out of Rotation…Maybe; Poor outing against

cleanText: Government bond prices fell across the world Thursday as investors scrambled to reassess their options a day after the head of the European Central Bank said . The yield on the benchmark German 10-year bond touched 0.99%, its highest level since September and close to double where it was at the start of the week. It recently eased back to 0.90%. Singapore's 10-year bond yield  in almost two years. The 10-year U.S. Treasury yield was at 2.38%, around 0.04 percentage point higher on Thursday. Yields rise as prices fall. In the U.S., stock futures indicated the S&P 500 index opening 0.5% lower. Changes in futures aren't necessarily reflected in market moves after the opening bell.
headline: Global Bonds Battered a Day After Draghi Comments; Yields on 10-year bunds reach highest level since September

cleanText: The roiling of the sovereign-debt markets, especially in Europe, has taken center stage this week. Draghi saying yesterday to prepare for volatility helped really get things cooking. And perhaps a selloff is just what he wants. Eurozone bond prices were obviously way overpriced earlier this year as many sovereign yields blew below zero. Now, prices are notably lower, which should substantially lessen the potential of the ECB losing money by maturity as the central bank continues its QE efforts. Ten-year Treasury yields have risen to 2.38% this morning. Meanwhile, S&P 500 futures are down 12 and the euro climbs toward $1.1335. Oil and gold are little changed. Write to Kevin Kingsbury at
headline: Maybe Draghi Wants Lower Sovereign-Debt Prices; U.S. stock futures are lower as the euro gains

cleanText: Former FIFA Vice President Jack Warner accused world soccer's governing body and its departing president, Sepp Blatter, of influencing his native Trinidad's general election in 2010. Mr. Warner, who has denied any wrongdoing, is among the more than a dozen current and former FIFA officials and sports-marketing executives  accusing them of complicity in alleged fraud spanning more than 20 years. In a televised address in Trinidad on Wednesday, Mr. Warner said he feared for his life after compiling a series of documents that he alleges prove links between FIFA and his nation's government.
headline: FIFA Ex-Official Jack Warner Drags Trinidad Government and Sepp Blatter Into Scandal; Former FIFA vice president accuses Sepp Blatter of influencing Trinidad’s 2010 election

cleanText: KIEV, Ukraine—International observers reported Thursday that Russia-backed rebels moved large numbers of heavy weapons toward Ukrainian government positions hours before an outbreak of deadly fighting that threatened a delicate cease-fire. While the observers didn't assign blame, the report from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe gives credence to Kiev's claims that the separatists started the Wednesday fighting,  since a cease-fire was signed in the Belarusian capital of Minsk in February. While Moscow and rebels blame Ukrainian troops for the battle, the OSCE report is likely to support a tough line on Russia at this weekend's summit of Group of Seven nations in Germany, which is expected to issue a stern warning to Moscow to help foster .
headline: Observers Say Rebels in Eastern Ukraine Moved Heavy Weapons Before Fighting; Ukrainian officials, separatist leaders blame each other for latest flare-up

cleanText: U.S. stock futures fell Thursday, on the heels on declines in European stocks and losses in government bonds across the globe. S&P 500 futures slipped 10 points, or 0.5%, to 2107. E-mini Dow futures lost 71 points, or 0.4%, to 18025. E-mini Nasdaq-100 futures fell 30 points, or 0.7%, to 4498. Changes in stock futures don't always accurately predict moves in the stock market after the opening bell. European stocks and German government bonds dropped. Germany's DAX lost 1.1% and France's CAC-40 fell 1.3%. The yield on the 10-year German bund hit 0.99% earlier Thursday, marking its highest level since September. In recent trade, the 10-year bund yield was at 0.90%. Yields rise as prices fall.
headline: U.S. Stock Futures Fall Amid Global Volatility; Government bonds have sold off in recent sessions, while U.S. stocks have been relatively quiet

cleanText: Jeb Bush, the former Florida governor and kin to two American presidents, is expected to formally begin his quest for the Republican presidential nomination June 15 in Miami. Mr. Bush has chosen Miami-Dade College, the largest and most diverse community college in the country, as the venue to announce his plans, reflecting his longtime focus on education and attachment to the multicultural community he has called home for decades. While an aide said he would announce a decision that day on whether to run, Mr. Bush has in essence been campaigning for six months, and his presence in the race for the GOP nomination is all but certain.
headline: Jeb Bush to Announce White House Plans June 15; Former Florida governor has been under pressure to make campaign decision official

cleanText: OMETEPE, Nicaragua—The Sandinista government, which expropriated vast tracts of land during its 1980s revolutionary phase, is again roiling the country as it prepares to seize rural properties. But this time, it is for a capitalist endeavor: a 172-mile canal connecting the Atlantic and Pacific. Nicaragua's planned route between the oceans could accommodate vessels more than four football fields long, too big even for the newly expanded Panama Canal. It would be the largest earth-moving project in history, according to Hong Kong Nicaragua Canal Development, or HKND Group, which has a 50-year concession to build and operate the canal. But to make room for the waterway, ports, roads and free-trade zones, the company says it needs 642 square miles. Nicaraguan government officials justify the pending expropriations, which would uproot 27,000 people, saying the canal will transform this impoverished Central American nation by creating 50,000 jobs and doubling the economy.
headline: Nicaraguan Canal Plan Riles Landholders; Sandinista push to build Chinese-led shipping route across country sparks concerns over property rights

cleanText: BEIJING—Salvage crews will begin righting an overturned passenger ship in the Yangtze River on Thursday night, three days after the vessel overturned in foul weather with more than 450 people on board. Authorities overseeing the disaster response made the decision to right the ship, state media said. The move, according to experts, means that rescuers believe no more survivors will be found inside the ship, the Eastern Star. Officials reported that only 14 survivors had been found, all within the first day after the accident. As of Thursday, the official death toll stood at 77, with the remaining 365 unaccounted for. As search and rescue work proceeded, cranes on barges were maneuvered into place Wednesday to prepare for the righting of the ship. The emergency response command center decided to begin the salvaging at 8 p.m. local time, the Xinhua News Agency reported.
headline: Work to Right Capsized Chinese Ship to Start Thursday Night; Cranes on barges maneuvered into place on Wednesday

cleanText: NEW DELHI—India's state-run Indian Oil Corp. and Hindustan Petroleum Corp. plan to buy crude from Iraq for strategic reserves and to use in times of crisis or oil-supply disruptions. Hindustan Petroleum Corp. said it a statement it has been in touch with Somo, the oil-marketing company of the Iraq government, to seek an allocation of 2 million barrels of crude oil in the coming month. The procurement comes after India's oil ministry asked Hindustan Petroleum and Indian Oil to purchase 4 million barrels of Basra light crude oil on behalf of Indian Strategic Petroleum Reserves, Hindustan Petroleum Corp. said in a filing to stock exchanges Thursday.

SBA Communications Corp. has authorized a $1 billion stock-repurchase plan, after completing its prior $300 million stock buyback plan last month. According to the Boca Raton, Fla.-based wireless communications company, the new plan has no deadline and shouldn't change the company's Ebitda targets. Purchased shares will be retired. Under its old plan, SBA had purchased 1.305 million shares, about 1% of shares outstanding.

Former Texas Gov. Rick Perry, who presided over the Lone Star State during a period of dramatic economic expansion but ran an error-plagued presidential campaign in 2012, formally declared Thursday that he is making a second run for the White House. Ahead of a speech later Thursday at which Mr. Perry is expected to formally announce his campaign, the RickPerry.org website posted “Perry for President" logos. The site contained a message from Mr. Perry, saying: “I am running for president, because I know our country's best days are ahead of us." Mr. Perry won a following among conservative Republicans during a record 14 years as governor by signing measures to restrict abortion, rein in personal injury suits and reduce taxes. As , he will emphasize his record of creating jobs while governor and tout his efforts to send Texas National Guard troops to secure the Mexican border.
headline: Former Texas Gov. Rick Perry to Run for President; Declaration made on website RickPerry.org

cleanText: Guotai Junan Securities Co. is set to join the list of Chinese brokerages taking advantage of China's booming stock markets through initial public offerings. Shanghai-based Guotai Junan, the country's third-largest brokerage firm by assets and its most profitable last year, won regulatory approval for a Shanghai IPO Thursday. It is already listed in Hong Kong. In a preliminary prospectus filed with the China Securities Regulatory Commission Thursday, Guotai Junan said it plans to issue up to 1.52 billion shares, or 10% to 20% of its total capital, to replenish its capital base and supply working capital. It didn't say how much it is seeking to raise.
headline: Guotai Junan Joins Parade of China Brokerage IPOs; Market boom continues to fuel offerings by companies in the stocks business

cleanText: LONDON—Lloyds Banking Group PLC will be fined around £100 million (around $153.4 million) following a long-running investigation into how it handled complaints from customers who were sold insurance products they didn't need, according to people familiar with the matter. The Financial Conduct Authority, which is expect to hand down the fine on Friday, probed how the bank managed third-party groups who were hired to deal with complaints from customers sold , according to regulatory filings. PPI was widely sold alongside an assortment of financial products, including loans and credit cards, to cover customers' repayments should they fall sick or lose their job. Since 2000 Lloyds sold an estimated 16 million such policies. The bank estimates it has settled around 45% of the polices sold since then, according to its annual report. So far the bank has set aside more than £12 billion to compensate customers. In 2013 the U.K. regulator fined the bank for delaying compensation payments for people sold PPI. Friday's fine is large in part because of the sheer number of mishandled complaints, according to one person familiar with the matter.
headline: U.K. Regulator to Fine Lloyds Around $153.4 Million; Fine largely due to mishandling of complaints relating to mis-sold insurance

cleanText: WASHINGTON—U.S. worker productivity fell in the opening months of 2015, a confirmation of the poor start to the year for the economy. The productivity of nonfarm workers, measured as the output of goods and services per hour worked,  in the first quarter, the Labor Department said Thursday. From a year earlier, productivity was up 0.3%. Economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal had forecast a 3% decline from the prior quarter.
headline: U.S. Productivity Falls 3.1% In First Quarter; Unit labor costs increase 6.7%

cleanText: WASHINGTON—The number of Americans seeking first-time unemployment benefits fell last week, a sign companies are laying off fewer workers and the economy continues to steadily add jobs. Initial claims for unemployment benefits, a measure of layoffs across the U.S., declined 8,000 to a seasonally adjusted 276,000 in the week ended May 30, the  said Thursday. Economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal had expected 279,000 new claims. The agency also said 284,000 claims were filed in the prior week, replacing its initial estimate of 282,000.
headline: U.S. Jobless Claims Fall to 276,000; Companies lay off fewer workers and the economy continues to steadily add jobs

cleanText: SINGAPORE—Antivirus software developer Avast Software is considering potential acquisitions and a public listing in the U.S. or Europe amid strong demand for its services, the company's chief executive said. While some competitors' businesses are shrinking or only seeing mixed success, Avast is “really the only growing consumer security company out there," Vincent Steckler told The Wall Street Journal in an interview Thursday. “Our core business is growing really strongly." The closely-held Prague-based company says it has more than 230 million active users globally, with a strong presence in the U.S., Europe and Latin America.
headline: Antivirus Firm Avast Mulls Acquisitions, Listing Amid Expansion Plans; Avast is growing at a time when its competitors are struggling, chief executive says

cleanText: BOSTON—A man who was fatally shot by antiterrorism investigators bought three large knives and indicated to a friend that he planned to attack police officers in Massachusetts this week, possibly beheading them, authorities said in court papers Wednesday. Usaamah Rahim,  a 26-year-old security guard, was killed by a Boston police officer and a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent Tuesday outside a drugstore in the city's Roslindale section, where he lived. Authorities said he was carrying a knife and advanced on investigators after they attempted to question him.  Mr. Rahim bought three “fighting" knives and a knife sharpener from Amazon last week—two Ontario Spec Plus Marine Raider Bowie fighting knives with 9.75-inch blades and an Ontario Knife SP6 Spec Plus Fighting Knife 8325, which has an 8-inch blade, according to an affidavit filed in federal court.
headline: Man Fatally Shot Under Terror Surveillance Allegedly Planned Beheading of Police Officer; Usaamah Rahim was suspected of sympathizing with

cleanText: SYDNEY—Confidence in Australia's economy was rattled Thursday by government figures showing a record trade deficit and stalled retail-sales growth in April. Economists had been expecting retail sales to climb by 0.3% from March following the previous month's 0.2% increase, but instead sales were flat in April. The disappointing data drove the Australian dollar down by more than half a U.S. cent as traders bet on the rising prospect of a further rate cut to shore up the ailing economy. Australia's benchmark stock index fell. The central bank has  to help the county transition away from a decadelong mining-investment boom . For the past few years, its policy makers have been hoping for other sectors, including retailing, construction and manufacturing, to pick up the slack. There have been two rate cuts already this year.
headline: Weak Sales, Record Trade Deficit Knocks Australian Economy; Disappointing data drove the Australian dollar down by more than half a U.S. cent

cleanText: DUBAI—Human rights groups and a labor union called on Thursday for Qatar to publish transparent figures on the number of deaths related to the 2022 World Cup construction preparations, urging the Gulf state to improve its labor laws and living conditions for workers. Qatar's human-rights record is in the spotlight , soccer's governing body. Tim Noonan, director of campaigns at the International Trade Union Confederation, said on Thursday that it estimates about 900 workers will die per year in Qatar ahead of the tournament.
headline: Qatar Called to Publish World Cup Worker Death Figures; Gulf state’s human-rights record in spotlight following launch of FIFA investigations

cleanText: TOKYO—Japanese e-commerce giant Rakuten Inc. said it plans to raise $1.5 billion from a new share offering to shore up its financial standing as it continues to look for growth through acquisitions. The company, led by billionaire Chairman Hiroshi Mikitani, said Thursday it would issue about 100 million shares to international and domestic investors, with the price to be determined in late June. The proceeds from Rakuten's first share issuance in nine years will mainly be used to pay down debt, much of it run up during the company's current spending spree as it strives to become a global provider of Internet content.
headline: Rakuten Plans to Raise $1.5 billion; Japanese e-commerce giant will shore up finances with share offering
What’s News: World-Wide
Scope of Pentagon’s Anthrax Blunder Widens;

cleanText: HARTFORD, Conn.—The Legislature approved a $40.29 billion, two-year budget late Wednesday that raises taxes on businesses and the state's wealthiest residents, despite objections from Republicans and some of Connecticut's biggest employers. The Democratic-controlled Senate passed the budget 19-17 about a half-hour before a midnight Wednesday deadline. The House of Representatives, also controlled by Democrats, narrowly approved the budget 73-70 after a marathon session that began Tuesday and ended around 10:30 a.m. Wednesday. Gov. Dannel Malloy, a Democrat, is expected to sign it.
headline: Connecticut Legislature Approves Budget; Governor is expected to sign $40.29 billion, two-year package that raises taxes on businesses, wealthiest residents

cleanText: Republican presidential candidate Carly Fiorina and her husband have a net worth of $59 million, her campaign said late Wednesday, making her one of the wealthiest candidates in the race so far. Mrs. Fiorina, a former Hewlett-Packard Co. chief executive, . The disclosure, required by law, allows candidates to reveal their assets and income in broad ranges. But Mrs. Fiorina went beyond the requirement, releasing tax returns from two recent years as well as precise figures for her assets. Mrs. Fiorina also included a thinly veiled jab at Hillary Clinton, the Democratic front-runner whom she says she is uniquely suited to oppose in the 2016 general election. Mrs. Clinton, who released her financial disclosure form last month, has been criticized by Republicans as overly secretive.

Molycorp Inc., the only U.S. miner and processor of rare-earths elements, plans to file for chapter 11 bankruptcy protection as soon as this month to cut its $1.7 billion debt load, according to people familiar with the matter. The Greenwood Village, Colo.-based company is completing a plan that would involve senior bondholders exchanging some or all of their debt for ownership of the company, some of the people said. It is exploring options such as an equity sale to junior creditors and shareholders to ensure the company would emerge in sound financial health, they added. Molycorp is also weighing an offer from the senior bondholders for a loan that would fund its operations during bankruptcy, the people said. Senior lender Oaktree Capital Management LP may also participate in that loan, they added.
headline: Rare-Earths Miner Molycorp Prepares to File for Bankruptcy Protection; Plan marks dramatic turn for only U.S. producer of elements used in a host of electronic devices

cleanText: Dish Network Corp. is in talks to merge with T-Mobile US Inc., people familiar with the matter said, a deal that would accelerate a wave of consolidation across the U.S. media and communications industries. The two sides are in close agreement about what the combined company would look like, with Dish Chief Executive Charlie Ergen becoming the company's chairman and his T-Mobile counterpart, John Legere, serving as the combined company's CEO, the people said. Tougher questions about a purchase price and the mix of cash and stock that would be used to pay for a deal remain unresolved, the people said. One of the people characterized the talks as at “the formative stage," and said an agreement might not ultimately be hammered out.

SHANGHAI—The three Chen sisters, along with two of their husbands and several friends from northern China, were virtually a tour group unto themselves when they boarded the Eastern Star in Nanjing last week. They packed Shanghai-style hairtail fish and stewed beef, worried the food outside their home city would be too spicy. Along the way, they snapped photos of each other at historical sites and on the deck of the ship as it passed below one of the massive bridges that traverse  In one, 69-year-old Chen Chengying smiled in a polka-dot pantsuit next to her sister, Longying, 63. The third sister, Guiying, 59, snapped a photo of them. On Monday night, hours before the ship capsized, Guiying sent the snapshots via the WeChat mobile-messaging service to her other sisters back home. “You saw our pictures, are they nice? Hahaha," she wrote.
headline: Ship Disaster on the Yangtze Tears Six Chinese Sisters Apart; Three of the six Chen sisters were among the hundreds missing after their ship capsized in China’s Yangtze River

cleanText: Greece's creditors stuck to a hard line but made some concessions in the outlines of a final deal presented to Athens on Wednesday to unlock much-needed aid before the government is expected to run out of cash this month. , which some European officials have described as a take-it-or-leave-it offer, marks a bid to break a  over the economic overhauls and budget cuts that Greece would need to carry out to receive additional bailout funds. The creditors' plan, which Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras discussed with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker in Brussels late Wednesday, would require the Greek premier to accept tough conditions that risk a political backlash in Athens.
headline: Greece’s Creditors Make Some Concessions as Showdown Approaches; Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras meets in Brussels with European Commission President Juncker
What’s News: Business & Finance

cleanText: It's one of the Broadway season's most beguiling mysteries. In the new musical comedy, “Something Rotten!," nominated for 10 Tonys, the big, show-stopping number, “A Musical," is jam-packed with nods to many famous musicals of the past, from “Oklahoma!" to “The Fantasticks."  The references are rapid-fire, taking the form of lyrics, musical phrases or visual cues. While the song is playing during act one, the theater is abuzz with audience members turning to each other, whispering “Was that from ‘Annie?" (Yes, it was. That is the one that everyone gets.) Until now, the show's creators, brothers Karey and Wayne Kirkpatrick, have been cagey about revealing the many Easter eggs planted in the nearly 9-minute song. Now, as a matter of public interest, they are disclosing the many Broadway references the song contains.
headline: The Tune That Samples Decades of Broadway Hits; The big number in ‘Something Rotten!’ is jam-packed with nods to many famous musicals of the past

cleanText: The name of the Spanish city of Alcora was misspelled as Ualcora in the dateline of  Wednesday about the Spanish economy.                 Interfax is an independent Russian news agency. It was incorrectly described as a Russian state news agency in  about doubts over plans to hold the next FIFA World Cup tournaments in Russia and Qatar.                 A Personal Journal article Tuesday about allergy season included a photograph of goldenrod; the caption incorrectly said it was ragweed. Male mulberry trees produce the pollen that causes allergies; a photo incorrectly showed a female of the species. Cherry trees, shown in another photo, are insect-pollinated and so generally aren't a problem for allergy sufferers.
headline: Corrections & Amplifications

cleanText: It isn't so often you go to a party in New York and two television stars make the motzi, or blessing, over a challah. But that was the case on Tuesday, at 583 Park Avenue. Mark Feuerstein of “Royal Pains" and Meghan Markle of “Suits" were the actors. Mr. Feuerstein is Jewish, and spontaneously rapped the v'ahavta prayer to prove it. Ms. Markle isn't Jewish, and, as Mr. Feuerstein called her, a “shiksa goddess." But, together, and with the help of a teleprompter, they acquitted themselves rather nicely. The event, a benefit for the UJA-Federation of New York's Entertainment Division, honored Bonnie Hammer, the chairman of NBCUniversal Cable Entertainment. Nielsen ratings on the challah haven't come in yet.
headline: Bread and Roses on a June Evening; MoMA’s annual Party in the Garden, plus challah at a UJA-Federation of New York benefit

cleanText: MOSCOW—Top Russian officials reassured the country that it would still host the World Cup in 2018, despite  Sepp Blatter, which a Kremlin spokesman described as unexpected. Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Russia's preparations to host the 2018 World Cup were continuing apace, despite the scandal enveloping the global soccer governing body, and Mr. Blatter's resignation Tuesday had come as a surprise to the Kremlin. “Work is continuing, cooperation with FIFA is continuing, and most importantly, Russia is continuing preparations for the 2018 World Cup," Mr. Peskov told Russian journalists in a briefing Wednesday. “All the plans are being implemented."
headline: Russia Says 2018 World Cup Preparations On Track; Sepp Blatter resignation, FIFA probe not affecting 2018 World Cup plans

cleanText: Europe's soccer-governing body on Wednesday said it had canceled an extraordinary meeting of its members that was slated for this week, after the surprise announcement by FIFA President Sepp Blatter that . The meeting, planned for Berlin, was called by Union of European Football Associations head Michel Platini to consider the group's options after Mr. Blatter was re-elected to his fifth term as president last week, despite calls for him to resign. Just days before, U.S. authorities charged more than a dozen people, including current and former FIFA officials, with corruption at the world's top soccer-governing body. Mr. Platini had been an outspoken critic of Mr. Blatter in recent days and said he wouldn't rule out the possibility that UEFA . But Mr. Blatter's unexpected announcement that he would step down takes pressure off him and his confederation to act. Fault lines were already appearing between Mr. Platini and key European members, such as France and Spain, which had supported Mr. Blatter in the election.

DUBAI—This week's  Sepp Blatter has turned a spotlight on Qatar, which is spending $200 billion to prepare to host the 2022 World Cup and . Qatar has said it welcomed any investigation into how the World Cup was awarded since twin probes against FIFA emerged last week. But Tuesday's decision by Mr. Blatter—the biggest champion of Qatar's controversial bid—to step down, amid a spending spree on stadiums, roads, rail and real estate, has sparked speculation about the economic hit the loss of the World Cup would bring.
headline: Blatter’s Resignation Raises Concerns About Qatar’s FIFA World Cup Prospects; Loss of 2022 tournament would have a big economic impact on country, which is spending $200 billion to prepare

cleanText: For more than 125 years, students at the Pratt Institute have come up with inspiring design concepts that delight the eye and aim to influence society. But the bright ideas that percolated inside the classroom didn't necessarily translate into the look of the school's main campus, in Brooklyn's Clinton Hill neighborhood. “The place looked like a barren pasture," said Bruce M. Newman, a Pratt trustee emeritus and alumnus who received a bachelor's degree in fine arts from the school in 1953 and an honorary degree in 1997.
headline: A Pratt Institute Lesson in Campus Design; The school’s own upgrades are a vast improvement, many say

cleanText: SEOUL—A top U.S. activist hedge fund is squaring off against the Samsung Group's owning family as it seeks to consolidate control of its sprawling empire. Elliott Associates LP said Thursday it has acquired a 7.12% stake in Samsung C&T Corp. and that a proposed takeover of the company by the Samsung Group's de facto holding company wasn't in the best interests of Samsung C&T shareholders. Cheil Industries Inc.'s proposed takeover of Samsung C&T “significantly undervalues" Samsung C&T, a spokesman for Elliott said.
headline: Elliott Associates Criticizes Proposed Takeover of

cleanText: Rachel Tsang, a homemaker from Canada, and her husband bought this 3,300-square-foot apartment in Hong Kong in September 2009. ‘I really liked the building,' Ms. Tsang says. ‘It's airy and open, but also feels very safe and secure.' The apartment is located in the Mid-Levels, an upmarket residential area known for its impressive skyline views of Hong Kong and easy access to the city's Central business district.
headline: Simple Elegance in a Hong Kong High-Rise; This 3,300-square-foot apartment in the city’s upscale Mid-Levels area has a spacious layout and expansive skyline views. —Patrick Brzeski

cleanText: Dallas At an opening at the Nasher Sculpture Center here last Friday, tech entrepreneur Derek Wilson wore Lanvin blue jeans under a white tailored Kris Van Assche shirt. His wife, Christen, wore Dior and Rosie Assouline. Their mix of revered and emerging fashion labels is at odds with Dallas's reputation for style, which remains mired in the 1980s when J.R. Ewing was the most love-hated character on television. The “Dallas" TV show and the glitzy spotlight it shone on the city ended in 1991, leaving its reputation for fashion frozen in time.
headline: Luxury Labels Take On Dallas, Where Runway Fashion Is ‘a Sport’; With a full slate of black-tie events and a dress-up tradition, the city is a hot market for young designers

cleanText: LOS ANGELES—A pipeline rupture that  near Santa Barbara last month occurred along a badly corroded section that had worn away to a fraction of an inch in thickness, federal regulators said Wednesday. The preliminary findings released by the federal Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration point to a possible cause of the May 19 spill that blackened popular beaches with crude oil and created a 9-mile slick in the Pacific Ocean. The agency said investigators found that corrosion at the break site had degraded the pipe wall thickness to 1/16 of an inch. Additionally, the report noted that the area that failed was close to three repairs that had been made to the pipeline because of corrosion after 2012 inspections.
headline: California Oil Spill Pipeline Was Badly Corroded, Government Report Finds; Rupture that spilled crude along coast occurred on a section worn away to a fraction of an inch

cleanText: COLUMBUS, Ohio—The unemployment rate here and in other thriving metropolitan regions across the U.S. is below where it was when the financial crisis blew a hole in the U.S. economy in 2008. Now, many American workers are asking: Where's my raise?  Questions about the slow pace of wage growth aren't only stumping workers, but also economists and policy makers at the Federal Reserve—with the answers weighing on households and the larger U.S. economy. When U.S. unemployment rates fall, conventional notions of supply and demand predict wages will go up as firms bid for increasingly scarce workers, and there are signs of that, for example, in building trades and restaurants. “Basic economics hasn't gone out the window," Loretta Mester, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, said in an interview. “When employment grows, wages will start to grow."
headline: U.S. Workers Ask: Where’s My Raise?A Wall Street Journal analysis points to constraints on pay, even as the U.S. nears full employment

cleanText: On Spotify, not all songs are created equal; sometimes not even the same song is created equal—at least when it comes to how its creators are compensated. According to an analysis of data supplied by Spotify AB to music publishers, it takes five to seven plays of a song on the streaming service's free “tier"— which makes its money from ads—to generate the same amount of royalties as a single play on Spotify Premium, which charges users $10 a month. Last December, a single play on Spotify Premium was worth an average of about 0.68 of a cent in royalties, according to the analysis, conducted by Audiam, a company that helps music publishers collect digital royalties. In the same month, a single play on Spotify Free was worth an average of about 0.14 of a cent, about one-fifth the value on the subscription. (Royalties generally are due to record companies and music publishers; how they are shared with performers and songwriters depends on their contracts.)
headline: How the Cash Flows in Spotify Streams; Songs on the free version pay a lot less in royalties, and that’s just one of the quirks

cleanText: A passenger ship carrying more than 450 people sank in the Yangtze River on Monday night. The fate of most of them remains uncertain.
headline: Photos: More Than 400 Missing

cleanText: Men may be able to get more wear out of that beloved old pair of pants than they realize. Menswear makers don't always broadcast it, but many will repair and restore the items you buy there, sometimes for unlimited time periods. Brooks Brothers, Paul Stuart and Allen Edmonds are among a number of brands that employ specialists who will repair torn jacket linings, replace frayed shirt collars and refurbish wingtips for any customer who knows to ask. The brands are hoping to further establish brand loyalty and ensure repeat business. “We want to have them as part of the family," says Jake Betteridge, the store manager at Paul Stuart's flagship on New York's Madison Avenue. Some men “get very attached to some of their garments."
headline: Don’t Throw Out Those Well-Loved Shoes; Many menswear makers will repair and restore the items they sell, often even after decades

cleanText: Owners of small businesses, from clothing retailers to restaurants, are increasingly signing up for subscriptions to cloud-based software, representing a fundamental shift in the way they use technology. Businesses with fewer than 20 employees last year spent about $630 on software, up from $590 in 2013, a 7% increase, according to Intuit, maker of the popular TurboTax tax-preparation software. Eighty-five percent of small businesses are planning to increase their spending on software in the next five years, Intuit added.
headline: Small Firms Shift Toward Cloud-Based Software; Many business owners increasingly want to access data from mobile devices

cleanText: Amazon.com Inc. recently agreed to reveal the  cloud-computing operations. Now customers are demanding that the company open up about AWS's electricity consumption. Hootsuite Media Inc., Upworthy and Tumblr, owned by Yahoo Inc., are among the 19 AWS customers that signed a May 27 letter to AWS chief Andy Jassy, asking him to release details about the company's “energy and carbon footprints and progress toward renewable energy goals." The customers seek “full disclosure of the energy mix" used by the company's data centers world-wide, said Aaron Budge, vice president of operations at Hootsuite, a vendor of customer-service software.
headline: Amazon Is Urged to Come Clean on Energy Use; Cloud-computing clients are seeking details on electricity consumption, renewable-energy goals

cleanText: To deal with water restrictions in the midst of a drought, some Californians are painting their lawns green while others opt for au naturel brown.
headline: California Drought Inspires Limits on Lawns

cleanText: Near the end of his freshman year at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Ari Weinstein was offered $100,000 to drop out of school. Mr. Weinstein, now 20, had grown up immersed in technology. He created a website at age 7, started a software company in high school and released an iPhone app his first week at MIT. The rest of his freshman year, he juggled classwork along with tending to the app. The $100,000, from a fellowship sponsored by billionaire Peter Thiel, offered Mr. Weinstein a shot at his dream: starting a company with friends. But he wrestled with the decision in the spring of 2014, worried that he was giving up on college too soon and afraid of disappointing grandparents who valued education. His mother had other concerns.
headline: College Dropouts Thrive in Tech; Quitting school to start a company used to be seen as risky; now an honor

cleanText: Mary Jo White took the helm of the Securities and Exchange Commission vowing to “expeditiously" finalize its mountain of postcrisis rules. Two years later, that pledge has been thwarted by bickering among its five members. The slow pace of progress has singled Ms. White out for criticism from both Republicans and Democrats, who have faulted her leadership or her approach to regulation and enforcement. The gridlock also has delayed the completion of some probes into financial misconduct. “I have more stamina than anyone I know and need all of it for this job," Ms. White told a colleague early in her tenure, referring to her demanding schedule, according to people familiar with the conversation.
headline: SEC Bickering Stalls

cleanText: Black & White 'Scope: International Cinema BAMcinematek 30 Lafayette Ave., Brooklyn (718) 636-4100 Through June 16 It's hard to imagine how the elegant mind games of “Last Year at Marienbad" could survive in the age of Tinder. Instead of circling around each other in a puzzling pas de deux at an opulent European resort, the cryptic suitors played by Delphine Seyrig (“A") and Giorgio Albertazzi (“X") would just swipe right and send provocative selfies, leaving nothing to the imagination. Luckily, this great whatzit of modern cinema was released in 1961. Saturday screenings of the surreal Alain Resnais–Alain Robbe-Grillet collaboration, which precursed “Lost" and “Mulholland Drive," are a highlight of this series, showcasing auteur classics made in black-and-white CinemaScope. Gabriel Figueroa Film Forum 209 W. Houston St. (212) 727-8110 Friday–June 18 He shot movies for John Huston (“Under the Volcano," “The Night of the Iguana"), Don Siegel (“Two Mules for Sister Sara") and John Ford (“The Fugitive"). But cinematographer Gabriel Figueroa (1907–1997) also framed more than 200 other films through his lens, working mostly in Mexico where he helped to shape a post-revolutionary vision of the country. This series features 19 titles, including a rich streak of Mexican Westerns, romantic melodramas and cabareteras—the “film noir soap opera musical"—such as “Victims of Sin," one of many collaborations with director Emilio Fernández. ‘We Are Still Here' Cinema Village 22 E. 12th St. (212) 924-3363 Friday–Saturday If the problem with most contemporary horror movies is the emphasis of special effects over characters—most of whom are disposable cliché—here's a surprising debut that cuts against the grain. Writer-director Ted Geoghegan takes a more nuanced (and spookier) European approach in this haunted-house drama, in which a grieving middle-aged couple (Barbara Crampton, Andrew Sensenig) relocates in hopes of a new life. Boy are they in for a surprise. As are audiences, who get real emotional stakes amid the inevitable splatter. Midnight shows only.
headline: Cryptic Suitors and Advice from a Trapeze Artist; ‘Last Year at Marienbad,’ ‘Spartacus & Cassandra’ and more in this week’s Repertory Film

cleanText: ALBANY—The future of a tax break that has saved New York City developers billions of dollars has emerged as the thorniest issue in the state capital, twisting political alliances, alarming the city's real-estate interests and serving as another wedge between the state's two top Democrats. The tax program, known as 421-a, has previously drawn the scrutiny of an ethics panel because it gives lucrative benefits to developers, who also are among the state's more generous political contributors. New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio and Gov. Andrew Cuomo, along with legislators, disagree on how to change the program so discussions are under way to extend it temporarily and convene a special legislative session in several months—or address it next year, according to people familiar with the negotiations.
headline: New York City Developers Are Wary Over Fate Of 421-a Tax Break; Future of program is thorniest issue in Albany; many legislators are wary of changes because of ethics scrutiny

cleanText: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey could see more changes at the top with two prominent board nominees from the real estate and financial industries. On Wednesday, Gov. Andrew Cuomo said he nominated Michael Fascitelli, a former president and chief executive of Vornado Realty Trust, and Tony James, the president and chief operating officer of private-equity firm Blackstone Group LP, as commissioners overseeing the Port Authority. The men must be confirmed by the New York state Senate to join the authority's 12-member board.
headline: Two Prominent Figures Tapped for Port Authority Board Spots; New York Gov.

cleanText: Safety authorities previously cited the Chinese tour ship that capsized on the Yangtze River for safety infractions, adding to questions about a tragedy that has left more than 300 people unaccounted for. Emergency teams found 39 bodies overnight, state broadcaster China Central Television reported Thursday morning on its verified microblog. That raises the official death toll in Monday's accident to 65, while the number of survivors remained at 14. Rescuers expanded the search area to about 130 miles downstream from the overturned hull of the passenger ship, which was carrying 456 people, many of them elderly.
headline: Chinese Ship That Sank in Yangtze River Was Cited for Safety Issues; The Eastern Star was held as part of a maritime safety campaign in 2013

cleanText: WASHINGTON—Former Rhode Island Gov. Lincoln Chafee joined the race for the Democratic presidential nomination, offering a campaign platform aimed at challenging front-runner Hillary Clinton on her foreign-policy record and firing up the progressive Democratic base. Mr. Chafee formally announced his candidacy in a speech at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., Wednesday evening, where he made the case for his long-shot 2016 bid by embracing a hodgepodge of international and domestic issues supported by many progressives in the Democratic Party. His presence in the race presents Mrs. Clinton with another challenger from the left. Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders and former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley contend Mrs. Clinton is out of step with her party on economic policy. Mr. Chafee argued the same on foreign affairs, making an issue of her 2002 vote to authorize the invasion of Iraq.
headline: Lincoln Chafee Joins 2016 Presidential Race; Former Rhode Island governor expected to criticize Hillary Clinton for her record on the Iraq war issue

cleanText: A dozen horses since 1978 have stood 1½ miles from racing immortality heading into the Belmont Stakes. All of them have failed.
