No one needs to be reminded of this fact less than Bob Baffert, the trainer of this year's Triple Crown hopeful, American Pharoah. After all, three of those 12 horses came from his stable. Baffert trained Silver Charm in 1997, Real Quiet in 1998 and War Emblem in 2002. Like American Pharoah, who arrived in New York on Tuesday afternoon for his own shot at racing history, all of them had won the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes, only to falter in the Belmont and see the Triple Crown slip away.
headline: Bob Baffert Hopes Fourth Time Is a Charm for the Triple Crown; American Pharoah’s trainer can end the 37-year Triple Crown drought if he learns from previous shortcomings at the Belmont stakes, and finds a little luck

cleanText: New York Lawmakers Arrested in Rent Rules Protest Several New York City and New York state lawmakers were arrested Wednesday outside Gov. Andrew Cuomo's office during a demonstration for stronger rent regulations in Albany.
headline: Greater New York Watch; A roundup of news from around the tri-state region

cleanText: SEATTLE—When he was perhaps the best pitcher in baseball, in the heady spring of 2014, Masahiro Tanaka would mix his nasty split-finger fastball with a slider, a sinking fastball, and ratchet his main fastball up to 95 mph when he needed it. Then, after he suffered a small tear in his pitching elbow last summer, Tanaka tried to reinvent himself with a different ratio of fastballs. Sometimes it appeared as though it was working. But he never looked the same as he had last year. Until Wednesday.
headline: Masahiro Tanaka Dominates in Return as

cleanText: You've no doubt heard of the Three Tenors. But how about the Five Cantors? They would be Avraham Fried, Netanel Hershtik, Yanky Lemmer, Joseph Malovany and Lipa Schmeltzer. And on June 16, they're giving a free concert of cantorial and contemporary Hasidic music at SummerStage in Central Park. It's part of KulturfestNYC, a weeklong festival of Jewish performing arts.
headline: Urban Gardner: Five Cantors and How They Got Into the Soul Business; The men have a deep respect for each other’s talents and for their Jewish musical heritage

cleanText: After 17 years in charge of world soccer's governing body, Sepp Blatter began his lame-duck period just before 7 p.m. on Tuesday evening. He closed the most turbulent week in FIFA's history by announcing that . The problem is that FIFA plans to take at least six months to complete this unprecedented process. Meanwhile, no one is quite sure what will happen. Mr. Blatter wasn't named , which led last week to charges leveled at more than a dozen current and former FIFA officials and sports-marketing executives accused of complicity in alleged fraud spanning more than 20 years.
headline: Sepp Blatter’s Lame-Duck Status Throws FIFA Into Limbo; FIFA president’s protracted transition out of office raises questions over what rest of term will bring

cleanText: J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. won a legal battle in its effort to avoid billions of dollars in potential liabilities from its purchase of Washington Mutual Inc.'s banking operations during the financial crisis. A U.S. District Court judge in Washington ruled Wednesday that the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. must shoulder certain legal claims stemming from decisions that Washington Mutual made before J.P. Morgan bought the business in 2008 at the behest of regulators.

American Pharoah faces tough competition when he runs for the Triple Crown at the Belmont Stakes on Saturday. But owner Ahmed Zayat and his family already took some friendly fire from rivals at the post-position draw, held Wednesday at Rockefeller Center. With a cheerful zinger, Jerry Crawford, whose partnership Donegal Racing owns Keen Ice (20-1), congratulated Zayat's son, Justin, on his recent graduation from New York University. “In Iowa, where I'm from," said Crawford, “We think one family celebration a season is enough."
headline: American Pharoah’s Belmont Stakes Run Starts From Post No. 5; A field of eight will run in the 1 ½-mile ‘Test of the Champion’

cleanText: BOSTON—A man who was fatally shot by antiterrorism investigators bought three large knives and indicated to a friend that he planned to attack police officers in Massachusetts this week, possibly beheading them, authorities said in court papers Wednesday. Usaamah Rahim, a 26-year-old security guard, was killed by a Boston police officer and a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent Tuesday outside a drugstore in the city's Roslindale section, where he lived. Authorities said he was carrying a knife and advanced on investigators after they attempted to question him. Mr. Rahim bought three “fighting" knives and a knife sharpener from Amazon last week—two Ontario Spec Plus Marine Raider Bowie fighting knives with 9.75-inch blades and an Ontario Knife SP6 Spec Plus Fighting Knife 8325, which has an 8-inch blade, according to an affidavit filed in federal court.
headline: Man Fatally Shot Under Terror Surveillance Allegedly Planned Beheading of Police Officer; Usaamah Rahim was suspected of sympathizing with

cleanText: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.—For a team that overhauled its front office and coaching staff after finishing with a 4-12 record last season, the Jets have surprisingly few tough choices and plenty of backup-plan options as they finish off-season training and prepare for training camp. Twenty of the 22 starting-lineup positions are essentially set. The most interesting position battle might be for the uninteresting position of right guard. The other spot is only sort-of undecided, but it's at quarterback. Head coach Todd Bowles on Wednesday repeated his mantra that the struggling Geno Smith remains the No. 1 guy over the veteran Ryan Fitzpatrick—for now.
headline: Jets Work Through Spring Practices With Few Lineup Questions; Twenty of the 22 starting-lineup positions are essentially set, with only quarterback and right guard remaining undecided

cleanText: SAN DIEGO—Mets pitcher Bartolo Colon hears you laughing at him, and he doesn't appreciate it.  Don't bother trying to deny it. He knows you chuckle every time he steps up to the plate. He knows the crowd roars whenever he makes contact with the ball and hauls his 285-pound frame to first base, as if his at-bats were  a perverse form of absurdist performance art.
headline: Bartolo Colon Takes Offense at the Ridicule of His Offense; The Mets’ pitcher set out to improve his hitting, and has exceeded his own expectations

cleanText: INSIDER TRADING             Day Trader, Friends Charged by SEC The Securities and Exchange Commission charged four individuals with insider trading, alleging they used confidential information ahead of secondary stock offerings to generate more than $4.4 million in illegal profits.
headline: Financial Briefs

headline: A Pratt Institute Lesson in Urban Design; The school’s reworking of its main campus is winning praise

cleanText: BRASÍLIA—Brazil's central bank raised its benchmark interest rate by a half-percentage point on Wednesday as inflation remained resilient despite strong signs of recession in Latin America's largest economy, a condition often referred to as stagflation. The bank moved the rate, known as the Selic, to 13.75% from 13.25%. The bank's goal is to slow the 12-month inflation rate to 4.5% by the end of 2016, from 8.2% in April. The decision by the central bank's policy makers was unanimous. The bank kept the wording of the announcement unchanged from the previous meeting, suggesting its monetary policy committee members want to leave open the option for more rate increases.
headline: Brazil Raises Key Interest Rate to 13.75% Amid Stagflation; Central bank wrestles with inflation combined with strong signs of recession

cleanText: WASHINGTON—The congressional tussle over easing regulation for the banking industry continued Wednesday with House and Senate Democrats introducing their own bill that would scale back certain post-financial crisis rules for small banks and credit unions. The legislation mirrors an amendment Democratic members of the Senate Banking Committee unsuccessfully offered during the of a  assembled by Senate Banking Chairman Richard Shelby (R., Ala.). The  leaves out several significant chunks of Mr. Shelby's bill, including provisions to overhaul the Federal Reserve and raise the asset-size threshold for which banks automatically qualify for tougher rules and oversight. The Democrats pitch to their Republican counterparts: Let's pass a bill that everyone supports--and that President Barack Obama definitely won't veto--and then we'll tackle the thornier issues raised by Mr. Shelby's bill.
headline: Democrats Offer Own Version of Banking Regulation Bill; Democrats say pass a bill that all can support, then tackle thornier issues

cleanText: Apple Recalls 222,000 Beats Speakers Apple Inc. is voluntarily recalling about 222,000 of its Beats Pill XL speakers in the U.S. after receiving eight reports that batteries overheated and one user was burned. Apple is also recalling about 11,000 of the portable capsule-shaped speakers in Canada, according to the Consumer Product Safety Commission.
headline: Digits: Blog Highlights

cleanText: Investment firm General Atlantic LLC is acquiring a majority stake in California-based makeup brand Too Faced, a fast-growing company with a nontraditional approach to high-priced cosmetics. Terms of the transaction weren't disclosed, but a person familiar with the matter said the deal values Too Faced Cosmetics LLC at roughly $500 million. The brand's annual revenue is about $150 million and sales are growing at more than 60% a year, according to the company. The deal includes debt financing. The company was recently put up for sale by its owner, private-equity firm Weston Presidio Capital, which has been a majority shareholder since 2012. The auction attracted interest from bidders including Estée Lauder Cos., the person said. An Estée spokeswoman declined to comment.
headline: Too Faced Cosmetics Gains New Investor;

cleanText: NOTE TO READERS: In April 2014, Medicare released 2012 billing data that suppressed payments to medical providers for services they rendered to small numbers of patients. Medicare has since revised its methodology to include additional payments made to providers, and re-released 2012 billing data in June 2015. For this reason, the total payment figures cited in stories published prior to June 2015 may differ from figures cited from June 2015 onward. The original data released can be seen , and updated figures for 2012, along with 2013 billing data, can be seen . A fast-growing Virginia laboratory has collected hundreds of millions of dollars from Medicare while using a strategy that is now under regulatory scrutiny: It paid doctors who sent it patients' blood for testing. Health Diagnostic Laboratory Inc. transformed itself from a startup incorporated in late 2008 into a major lab with $383 million in 2013 revenues, 41% of that from Medicare.
headline: MEDICARE UNMASKED; A Fast-Growing Medical Lab Tests Anti-Kickback Law; Firm Paid Doctors Who Sent Blood for Tests; 'One Word Makes It Legal'
